div.head:
TRACES OF MAMMALIA IN THE NEW RED SAND-
STONE (grès bigarré) OF HILDBURGHAUSEN
IN GERMANY, COMMUNICATED TO THE ACA-
DEMY OF SCIENCES OF FRANCE, BY M. DE
HUMBOLDT, AUGUST 19.
div.p:
About a year since, a distinguished savant, M. Seigler,
observed the impressions of the feet of some animals on
the surface of the sandstone, in a quarry near Hildburg-
hausen. Living animals had evidently made these impres-
sions on the sandstone while it was in a soft state, and they
appeared to have walked over the sand in various directions.
There are impressions of the feet of several small animals,
but the most important are those of some large mammalia.
From a careful examination of the impressions last men-
tioned, it is inferred that they have been made by the feet
of an animal of the marsupial order (that is, of animals
bearing their young in a pouch like the kangaroo), but the
form and direction of the fingers and toes are unlike those
of any known recent animals. In a large slab of the sand-
stone deposited in the museum at Berlin, the impressions
are shewn in relief; those of the hind feet indicate a very
fleshy foot. The animal appears to have trod with all its
weight; its step resembles that of the bear, a sort of am-
ble, the anterior right extremity being placed very regularly
near the hind right foot. Even in the forefeet the thumb is
separated from the other fingers, almost as in the quadri-
mana. Some of the impressions of the hind feet are
twelve or thirteen inches long. Independently of the
nature of the animal which has occasioned these im-
pressions, the phenomenon in question is of vast import-
ance to geologists, because it adds another to the few
authenticated instances hitherto known, of the existence of
mammalia at a very remote perios of the earth—a period
immediately subsequent to the deposition of the coal
measures. At that epoch we know there were vast islands
or continents clothed with vegetation, and these may have
been inhabited by mammiferous animals. This discovery
will in nowise affect the well established fact of the vast
preponderance of enormous reptiles at that period of the
secondary formations so emphatically called the age of rep-
tiles, and which a late writer in a Bridgwater Essay has so
strangely attempted to refute! But what vagaries will not
an author indulge in, who imagines that the Iguanodon and
other enormous fossil saurians may still exist in some
“subterranean metropolis of the reptile world” (vide
Kirby’s Essay), and explains the absence of the fossil
remains of man by assuming that the Almighty willed that
the bones of the antediluvians should be concealed for ever
from our view!
